title: Wal-Mart Plans Corporate Job Cuts - Yahoo Finance
text:
Slowing sales have forced Wal-Mart (NYSE: WMT) to cut around 450 jobs, according to The Wall Street Journal. 
The staff reductions, however, won't affect the workforce in the company's stores. Instead, the newspaper reported, the layoffs will take place at the company's headquarters in Bentonville, AR and are expected to include some executives ranking as high as vice president.
"After months of evaluation, we've concluded there is an opportunity to better position our Home Office teams to move with speed and purpose," CEO Doug McMillon wrote in a memo sent Friday to staff. The company is at "an important time in our history," he added. "This in part means pulling back in some areas and investing in others."
Why is Wal-Mart doing this?
The moves, according to the Journal , are designed to bring the home-office staff more in line with the retailer's shifting priorities. That means some of the cuts are being made to make way for hires with more experience in digital sales. The company also plans to focus more on the in-store experience for customers.
Wal-Mart has already begun making some changes, but in August, the retailer reported a 15% drop in net quarterly profit. The corporate layoffs were probably hastened by declining results.
This is not a small change
Laying off top-level executives and corporate managers essentially puts all Wal-Mart employees on notice. It's a serious message that the company not only intends to make changes but also intends to make them quickly.
The world's largest retailer seems to be accepting that the status quo will no longer work -- a sign that top management understands that digital competitors threaten its core business and that meeting that challenge requires different thinking.
